    Head 46 -

    The Chairman: The Question is,

    "That the sum to be allocated for Head 46 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (1) of subhead 1."

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Wee Toon Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, last night I

Column: 1164

read to the House the legal opinion given by the State Advocate-General's Chambers on the point of holding secret ballots where there is a certified and registered collective agreement. The Member for Thomson accused us of trying to evade this issue. Here are the facts of the matter.

    C.K. Tang Ltd, and the Singapore Manual and Mercantile Workers Union signed a collective agreement which was certified by the Industrial Arbitration Court on 15th March, 1961. The agreement was for two years, from 15th March, 1961, to 14th March, 1963. On 5th December, 1961, that is two years ago, the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union claimed to represent the majority of the employees of C. K. Tang, and this union requested the Commissioner for Labour to conduct a secret ballot to determine union representation. The Commissioner for Labour, who then was Mr Kok Ah Loy and not Mr Pang Tee Pow, referred this matter to the State Advocate-General's Chambers for advice, and the S.A.G.'s Chambers gave advice which I read last night. The union was, therefore, advised accordingly. The matter then rested at that stage without being pursued further by this union.

    It was after two years, that is on 13th March, 1963, that the S.B.H.E.U. again took up this matter. The present Commissioner for Labour, Mr Pang Tee Pow, then told the union that it could not proceed with a secret ballot because of legal advice being given. However, in the meantime, he again referred the matter to the State Advocate-General for clarification. The S.A.G.'s Chambers took some time and it was only on 30th April, 1963, that the Commissioner for Labour was advised that he could proceed to hold a secret ballot in cases where there were certified and registered collective agreements.

    From then onwards, any dispute on the question of representation of unions is always resolved by way of a secret ballot. Therefore, a secret ballot was held in the C. K. Tang case sometime after April.

Column: 1165



    Mr Speaker, Sir, last night the Member for Thomson also made an accusation that the present Commissioner for Labour, Mr Pang Tee Pow, is biased and is acting on instructions. I will reveal to this House the facts of the other two cases so that the House will be able to arrive at a conclusion as to whether or not the Commissioner for Labour, as a civil servant, really acted on legal advice and according to the statute of the State.

    Take the case of the Plywood dispute which hitherto has had dealings with the Singapore General Employees' Union. On 23rd February, 1963, the Singapore Manual and Mercantile Workers Union approached the Commissioner for Labour to hold a secret ballot to determine union representation. The S.M.M.W.U., on 23rd February, that is, before clarification was given to the Commissioner for Labour on 30th April, also informed this union, which the Member for Thomson accused as belonging to the P.A.P., that no secret ballot could be held because of a legal ruling.

    Again in the case of Seiclene, as late as 16th April, I think, the S.M.M.W.U. approached the Commissioner for Labour to hold a secret ballot to determine union representation. Similarly, the Commissioner for Labour again rejected the request because of the legal ruling.

    So all these cases pertaining to secret balk: were only disposed of after 30th April, 1963, when the Commissioner for Labour was advised that, though there may be a certified and registered collective agreement, a secret ballot can be conducted. From that date onwards, all cases that were held up because of this ruling had been disposed of by way of secret ballot.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Thomson also claimed yesterday that the S.A.T.U. group of unions believe in maintaining industrial peace with justice through the machinery of the Industrial Relations Ordinance. I think all the workers know how sincere the Member for Thomson is with regard to this matter. He cited the case of the dispute between the S.B.H.E.U. and

Column: 1166

Fraser & Co. In this particular case, the union managed to reach agreement through direct negotiations with the employer on all points except the clause on retrenchment. Immediately after the deadlock, the union took it upon itself to lead the workers to go on strike, instead of adhering to the Industrial Relations Ordinance which provided that the next step the union should have taken was to notify the Commissioner for Labour under section 19 that they had reached a deadlock although they had direct negotiations. Had that been done, the Commissioner would have arranged for a further conciliation. But in this case, the union did not resort to this procedure. They deemed fit to resort to direct action.

    In the Industrial Relations Ordinance, there are so many procedures to go through where every facility and every assistance and every effort can be made to settle a dispute. Just now, I referred to section 19. Under section 19 where the Commissioner fails to effect a conciliation, he could notify the Minister for Labour that no further progress could be made through conciliation. The matter could then be considered by the Minister as to whether it should be referred to arbitration or further conciliation could be made through his good offices. But no, the Union did not avail itself of all these facilities. So this is one of the classic cases where the Member for Thomson incited and misled the workers to go on strike. And when he is in a fix, he always puts the blame on the Minister for Labour or the Labour Ministry that we make no attempt to help them resolve their trade disputes. In this case, though they went on strike, nevertheless our conciliation officer on his initiative, immediately the strike was on, approached both parties to resume negotiations at the office.

    Another case where the S.A.T.U group of unions deliberately by-passed the conciliation machinery and the Industrial Relations Ordinance was the recent dispute in Singapore Oxygen Ltd. This case involves the question of transfer. The union took up this matter with the management. No progress could be made through direct negotiations. Immediately after that, the union

Column: 1167

took it upon itself to lead the workers to go on strike.

2.45 p.m.

    So in this case, it was the management itself which referred the matter to the Labour Department and asked it to assist in effecting a conciliation. Immediately upon this request, the Conciliation Office brought the two parties together and tried to resolve this matter. After several meetings, the dispute was then resolved on certain terms. Among the terms of the settlement arrived at was that this matter was to be referred to arbitration. Here again, this is a matter of interpretation. The union could have approached the management and suggested, after the deadlock, to refer the matter to arbitration. No, they went on strike. So after they went on strike and failed, they put the blame again on the Labour Ministry.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday the Member for Thomson said that he was sincere in making use of the conciliation machinery and the Industrial Relations Ordinance.

    Mr S. T. Bani (Thomson): Your record shows that!

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Yes. There is a letter here. After the settlement, the management wrote to the union saying, "All right, according to our terms of settlement, we are to refer this matter to arbitration." The employer asked the union to sign a joint application to refer the matter to arbitration. But what was the reply from the union? They said, "No, we are not interested in referring it to arbitration. If you want to do so, you do it by yourself." There you are, Mr Speaker, Sir. This is the conduct of this unionist who, in this House, claims that he is being deprived of the machinery and that we are playing politics in dealing with trade disputes - [Interruption] These are the facts. There are letters here in the file ---

    Mr Bani: What did the secretary reply?

    The Chairman: Order.

Column: 1168



    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, last night the Member for Thomson also said that we were deviating from our labour policy. The Minister for Labour had in his reply referred him to our labour policy which we have enunciated in our Five-Year Election Programme. If he verifies from the programme and the work we have done in the Labour Ministry, he can hardly find anything to show that we have fallen short of our election manifesto.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we know, of course, that it is a waste of time for us to convince or persuade the Member for Thomson to agree that we have strictly followed our labour policy which we have enunciated in our election programme. We know that according to him, the means justify the end, that is, even if the workers are to be sacrificed or they are to suffer, it is immaterial as long as he can achieve his ulterior motive by all these means, that is, to introduce a foreign ideology to this country. Whereas on our side, Mr Speaker, Sir, we believe in our basic political philosophy and we are going to go about it by peaceful revolution. Therefore, we state that that is why there is a basic difference between the Member for Thomson and our side. Therefore, the machinery and the facilities; that prevail in the State are detrimental to the manner and activities of the Member for Thomson, because you are aware, Mr Speaker, Sir, that from time to time it is announced in the paper that workers have left the S.A. T.U. group of unions and joined the other unions, because the workers are fed up with them. They have been misled and a classic case was Borneo Motors, where their backroom boy, Mr Lu Shee Peng, fully realised that, in the agreement, the understanding reached was that the company would endeavour to pay an annual bonus of one month's salary or more within the terms of this agreement. This agreement was entered into on 1st July, 1961. For the year 1961, the union had advised the employees - their members then - to accept the rate of bonus as stipulated in the agreement reached. But in 1962, they deliberately misled the workers into believing that they could ask for more

Column: 1169

bonus. All right, even if they thought they had a case to do so, then the proper and peaceful way, without causing lot, of suffering to the workers, would be to refer this matter to the Arbitration Court, since this was not a question of bargaining over the quantum of the rate. It was just a question of interpretation of the clause. But, no. Again the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union led the workers on a strike. After the management had stood firm and pointed out the legal position of this case, they then realised that they had again misled the workers. In this case, they forced the workers to go back to work. There is no time for me to read through all the circulars put up by the members who were then in their union. These members were suddenly then told that they were expelled. They refused to go back to work. They were asked to call off the strike. They were first asked to go on strike; the union tried to deceive them that there was a case for them to ask for more bonus. After the union failed, they realised the legal position there and then they forced the workers to call off the strike. The workers then turned round and said, "Now, what is this? You have asked us to go strike because there is a case for more bonus. How is that you want us to call off the strike and go back to work without anything?" Therefore, the workers put up some arguments with the Member for Thomson. The Member for Thomson knew that it was very embarrassing. The only simple way of doing it is, as I have said just now, as long as the means justify the end, he just cuts them off. The workers, fortunately, were conscious of the consequences, because the management was already on the verge of serving them with notices of termination of services. They immediately approached the Labour Ministry for assistance. It was only at our intervention that the workers were not made to suffer unduly.

    The Member for Thomson also accused us of playing politics in dealing with trade disputes. Mr Speaker, Sir, everyone in the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union knows what the Member for Thomson is aiming at,

Column: 1170

and how they are going to make use of them. You will remember, Mr Speaker, Sir, immediately after the action in February taken by the Internal Security Council, the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union held a meeting in the Hokkien Huay Kwan. They passed a resolution, the usual thing, demanding the release of their trade unionists. They printed this resolution on paper. Then they asked their usual runners to go to every branch to force them to sign, saying that they must sign individually, each one of them, one copy saying that they supported the resolution, to show that it was genuine that the workers were up in arms against the Government. Not only that, Mi. Speaker, Sir, the workers were asked by force to donate one day's wages to support the detainees' families, not by voluntary donations. It was by force, otherwise they would be subjected to intimidation. I have often heard workers who are in the Singapore General Employees' Union say, "Though the union may have obtained one or two cents increase for me, every month or every now and then, I will be asked to contribute either to a strike fund, a Barisan rally or legal fees. In the end I have suffered a loss instead of gain by joining the union." That is a fact. The Member for Thomson can clarify it from his own members. There is a recent case of United Engineers when an old man had the courage to stand up and fight against the chairman of his own branch. He refused to contribute to this fund, because he had his own political convictions. He said, "I refuse to. I do not want to involve myself in these political manoeuvres." What did the branch do? The Singapore General Employees' Union used pressure on the employer and forced the old man to be sacked from the firm. This is on record. If the Member for Thomson wants any time, we can ask the Press to hold a Press conference and ask the workers to come and reveal the story. That is a fact ---

    Some hon. Members: Shame!

    The Chairman: Order.

Column: 1171



    Mr Wee Toon Boon: And again, they say they are always acting in the interests of the workers. But as I have pointed out just now - [Interruption]

    The Chairman: Order. This item goes on till 3.15 p.m. There will be plenty of opportunity for Members to speak.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Everyone knows that in the Bus Workers Union, they go and tell the employers that as a union, in principle, they should have the right to recommend workers to be employed in the firm whenever recruitment is made. Of course, in that case, their argument was that in 1955, there was a group of workers who were dismissed. They said they were wrongfully dismissed because, at that time, they said there were riots and industrial action. So on that ground, the management conceded to their demand. But everyone in the Bus Workers Union and all Singapore bus workers know that that right was fought for by the workers themselves in order to bring back their colleagues into employment. But instead of using it for the good of the ex-employees, the Member for Thomson's colleague, Mr Fong Swee Suan, used that right to recruit Barisan cadres into the Bus Company. He cannot deny that. All the bus workers are challenging him. Mr Tan Say Kam, who is the secretary of that union, was being pestered and he had to hide himself on certain occasions, because groups of workers were chasing after him. That is a tact. He cannot deny that. [Interruption]

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I think probably I will have to conclude because of the time limit ---

    The Minister for Health and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): We all like to hear more.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: The Member for Thomson accused us by saying that the basic point in our labour policy is the reunification of the trade union movement. Yes, Mr Speaker. Sir, the word "reunification" to the Member for Thomson means that all workers should be grouped and dumped on the laps of those pro-Communist agents, so that

Column: 1172

they can manipulate them. Mr Speaker, Sir, that definitely is not our labour policy. We say that we want to promote a united democratic and independent trade union movement. That is our object, and that is not the way as the Member for Thomson puts it.

    So, Mr Speaker, Sir, all the workers have now realised - [Interruption] Yes, it is quite true. They are coming out batch by batch ---

    The Chairman: Order. I think that point has been covered by the Minister for Labour, the switch-over of labour unions.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: What I am trying to emphasise now, Mr Speaker, Sir, is that the workers have now realised that they are not going to be made use of as tools for the interests of the Member for Thomson. They have said in the past that those that have switched from the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union are the white-collars. Last night they accused us saying that that we held in contempt the English-educated class. But he is now saying that those chaps who drifted to us were English-educated ---

    Mr Bani: When did I say that?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: You refer to your record. Now, the industrial workers from the General Employees' Union are coming out batch by batch. This morning in Pepsi-Cola, known as the Union Ltd., a ballot was held. These are the Chinese-educated industrial workers. Out of 146 employees, 133 voted in the secret ballot and 101 voted for the Singapore Manual and Mercantile Workers Union; only 27 indicated that they were not members of the Singapore Manual and Mercantile Workers Union. So I presume that this can be an indication that there are only 27 members now who are members of the Singapore General Employees' Union.

3.00 p.m.

    As I said last night, I quite appreciate how anxious and frightened the Member for Thomson is getting nowadays.

    Mr Bani: Sir, I suggested last night that the Parliamentary Secretary and his

Column: 1173

Minister should bring the whole of the Ministry of Labour to this Chamber so that they can refer to all their files. It appears that they have at least half the Ministry here.

    The Chairman: Half the Ministry?

    Mr Bani: In terms of documents and files, Sir.

    The Chairman: I see.

    Mr Bani: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is only a quarter of an hour, and it is not possible for me to touch on every single case that the Parliamentary Secretary raised in the course of his speech. Therefore, I just want to confine myself to one or two points and also to explain our basic accusation that the Government's labour policy is a policy of convenience to the Government. I said last night that they had a very inconsistent labour policy because the concentration given in solving trade disputes was political and not on the merits of trade disputes as such.

    Sir, I would like to take the case of Fraser and Co, which is a very recent case. The Parliamentary Secretary just said that an agreement had been reached between the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union and the employer on all claims that were submitted by the union before the strike took place. Sir, that is correct. That is so. But in the usual style of fabrication, he has seen fit not to tell the whole truth. Sir, negotiations commenced and were concluded on all items submitted by the union to the employer under section 16 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance as claims of the members. After the settlement was reached in a peaceful atmosphere, the employer brought up the question of retrenchment. The employer wanted an item to be included in the collective agreement covering retrenchment. Sir, the union objected to this. In this connection, Mr Speaker, I would like to draw the attention of the House to section 27 (a) of the Industrial Relations Ordinance. This is a recent amendment which was introduced by the Government last year.

    `Any person or trade union which enters into negotiations in relation to

Column: 1174

industrial matters otherwise than in accordance with the provisions of this Part of this Ordinance shall be guilty of an offence under this Ordinance.' Sir, the provisions in this Ordinance for a negotiation are sections 16, 17, etc. In section 27 (a), employers are also included. If the employer wants to introduce an item to be included in a collective agreement, the employer should serve under section 16 as provided. En the case of Fraser & Co., the employer did not do this. Surely the union was right in insisting that the retrenchment question could not be included in the collective agreement. So the strike took place because the employer was insistent.

    The conciliation officers of the Ministry of Labour who handled this dispute know the facts. Only two days ago we received the letter.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, on a point of explanation.

    Mr Bani: No, Mr Speaker, I do not intend to give way because there is not the time - [Interruption]

    The Chairman: Order.

    Mr Bani: Mr Speaker, there is not the time, and I am sure it is only fair that I try and explain one or two points that the Parliamentary Secretary raised just now which gave a completely distorted picture of the facts.

    Sir, that was in the case of Fraser. Only two days ago, we received the letter from the conciliation officer who informed us that he regrets he cannot solve this problem because the employer does not want to concede at all. The current situation in the dispute is that the employer wants to sack all the workers. As far as the employer is concerned, he has sacked all the workers and they are no more employees of Fraser and Co., and, therefore, the Singapore Business Houses Employees Union cannot enter into negotiations. This again is a violation of a provision in the I.R.O. There is a provision which says that no employer can victimise workers for having taken industrial action. The employer also says that the workers had breached the contract of service by staying away from work because they were on strike. Sir, a strike, I would like to

Column: 1175

point out, is a legitimate weapon guaranteed to the workers under the laws of the country, and, therefore, that again does not arise.

    The next point I would like to deal with is ---

    Mr Byrne: No such law.

    Mr Bani: --- the question of secret ballot. Sir, what the Parliamentary Secretary and the Minister have said, I repeat, only confirms what I have said, namely, the Ministry has no consistent policy. The Minister himself or the Parliamentary Secretary admitted that there were two opinions given to this interpretation of secret ballot in the context of an industry where a collective agreement exists. Sir, we know how these opinions were got. We know why they were got and we know how they were applied.

    Sir, while, on the one hand, the Ministry refused to hold a secret ballot on the ground that there was a collective agreement in force, on the other hand, there were workers switching sides in certain firms where there existed collective agreements. So if one goes through the list of these switch-overs, one will note that, in some cases, switch-overs took place, although there was a collective agreement.

    Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary said that we were informed of the reasons why a secret ballot was refused. This is untrue. We were not even given a reply to letters that we wrote to the Commissioner for Labour. It is because of this. Mr Speaker, that last night I said that it is regrettable that the Commissioner for Labour, who is a public servant, plays politics also. I said that we appreciated the work of the majority of the labour conciliation officers. But I cannot say the same for the Commissioner for Labour. His conduct has been such that he has treated large groups of unions with a political bias. Yesterday it was reported in the papers. Mr Speaker, he talks of anti-national elements being a threat to Singapore while he is in Geneva. I do not know who wrote the speech for him - by the Minister for ---

Column: 1176



    The Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Pang Boon): He is delivering the speech on my behalf.

    Mr Bani: But the papers did not say that. Perhaps it was a speech written, as the Minister says, by himself. Sir, this question of we being dangerous Communists who extort the workers, squeeze money out of them, force them to sign circulars, etc., I think, is too stupid a charge for me to reply. I can only say that the Government Benchers must have some respect for the intelligence of the workers. Sir, we do not despise people like they do.

    Sir, the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union is just one union. The total membership of that union is in the region of 10,000. The 40 odd unions, which are directly affiliated to S.A.T.U., represent over 100,000 workers. I think it is insane for anyone to suggest that 100.000 human beings can be intimidated by us. We do not have the things they have - the police; the State machinery. We have nothing to threaten them with.

    An hon. Member: Thugs!

    Mr Bani: They have got thugs. The Secretary of the Singapore Bus Workers Union was beaten up by thugs who were employed by the Manual and Mercantile Workers Union. They do this. They are talking of thugs! Sir, as an incentive to get some leading workers to work for them they have a few agents, discredited and questionable characters like T. V. Gomez, who spent money taking chaps to bars and indulging in everything under the sun which is questionable and immoral. Sir, I am prepared to substantiate everything that I say here. If the Government wants, they can give me the opportunity, and I will have sufficient witnesses to show which bars are frequented, how much money is used, where this money comes from. And they talk of us using thugs! I do not think anybody can seriously believe that if we really use thugs, the Government will say, "Jolly good, you use thugs. We will just keep quiet." They will lock us up. Sure, they will do. Sir, they are waiting for the opportunity to smack us down.

Column: 1177



    They dare not arrest the Assemblymen under the P.P.S.O., but they are waiting for an opportunity. I am sure they must be very sorry that they have still not got me because I have been a little slippery.

    Head 47 -

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 47 be reduced by $100.

    Sir, one of the benefits - if I may say so - which I hope will ensue for Singapore out of the recent drought is the realisation by the Prime Minister that trees are an essential commodity which, if' not looked after and planted from time to time, will eventually involve the country in rainless days.

    Sir, when the City Council was a going concern, there used to be a department which was specially entrusted with the planting of roadside trees, pruning them, looking after them, bringing them down and replacing them wherever necessary. Since the present Government took office, they have wound up the City Council and with it has gone the incentive for the department which was looking after trees and the planting of trees.

    Now it is a phenomenon of recent times that housing estates are springing up in large numbers. Large areas which have been wooded are being constantly felled down and houses being erected, with the result that a lot of trees have

Column: 1178

been brought down in Singapore and they have not been replaced. Roads have been put through these housing estates and when you visit these housing estates - although we have nice houses and nice gardens - you will find that they are bereft of roadside trees or big trees.
